senses.de: A vehicle used to travel on water
senses.ex: The ship crossed the Atlantic in five days.

Tips.title: Water Travel
Tips.description: Used for watercraft larger than boats, usually ocean-going and with multiple decks.
Tips.example: Giant ships transport goods across seas.

Tips.title: Literary Imagery
Tips.description: 'Ship' in literature often symbolizes a journey, exploration, or adventure across the sea.
Tips.example: In the story, the ship became a metaphor for his quest for knowledge.

Tips.title: Historical Context
Tips.description: The term 'ship' evokes images of historical exploration, trade, and naval warfare.
Tips.example: Ancient ships like the Vikings' allowed for pivotal explorations.

senses.de: To send something, especially goods or a message, somewhere
senses.ex: The company ships its products all over the world.

Tips.title: Commerce
Tips.description: Often used in a business context to describe the act of sending products to customers.
Tips.example: The warehouse ships orders within 24 hours.

Tips.title: E-Commerce Usage
Tips.description: Commonly used in online shopping to refer to the delivery process.
Tips.example: The online store offers free shipping on all orders.

Tips.title: Logistics
Tips.description: 'Ship' can imply international logistics and the challenges of global trade.
Tips.example: The company has to navigate customs regulations to ship abroad.

senses.de: To take someone or something to a place, especially using a ship
senses.ex: The prisoners were shipped off to a deserted island.

Tips.title: Forced Movement
Tips.description: Can suggest compulsory relocation, often with a sense of urgency or under duress.
Tips.example: Convicts were shipped to penal colonies in the 1800s.

Tips.title: Military Context
Tips.description: Used in a military sense to send troops or supplies, usually overseas.
Tips.example: Troops were shipped out to the conflict zone last week.

senses.de: The skill or art of managing a ship or aircraft
senses.ex: He is studying for a degree in ship management.

Tips.title: Specialized Skill
Tips.description: Indicates a very specific set of skills required for professional maritime operations.
Tips.example: Good ship management is crucial for a successful voyage.

senses.de: In fandom, to support or have a particular romantic pairing between characters
senses.ex: I totally ship these two characters in the series.

Tips.title: Fan Culture
Tips.description: This informal use arises from fan communities and involves rooting for relationships.
Tips.example: I ship those characters because they have great chemistry.

Tips.title: Not Literal
Tips.description: Does not involve actual boats or shipping; it's about characters in stories.
Tips.example: Fans often ship characters who aren't together in the actual plot.

Tips.title: Emotional Connection
Tips.description: Expresses emotional investment in the relationship between fictional characters.
Tips.example: It’s easy to ship characters when their stories make you feel invested in them.

Barge.wordDefinition:
A barge is a flat-bottomed boat used for transporting goods on rivers and canals.

It is typically not self-propelled and relies on being pushed or towed by a tugboat. Barges have a large flat deck and are used for carrying cargo like coal, grain, or construction materials.

Unlike barges, ships are typically self-propelled and have a more complex design with multiple decks and compartments.

In summary, barges are used for transporting goods on rivers and canals, while ships are used for transportation on open seas or oceans for various purposes.

Barque.wordDefinition:
A barque is a type of sailing vessel with three or more masts and square sails on the foremast, but with a fore-and-aft rig on the other masts.

A barque is a smaller sailing vessel with a particular rigging system used primarily for coastal trade, while a ship is a larger vessel with a more versatile rigging system used for various purposes, including long-distance travel.

Boat.wordDefinition:
Both boat and ship are words for watercraft, but they are used to describe different things.

A boat is a smaller vessel, usually under 100 feet in length, that is used for personal or recreational purposes, like fishing or skiing.

If it's big enough to carry cargo or passengers, it's a ship. If it's smaller and used for pleasure, it's a boat.

Craft.wordDefinition:
Craft refers to a small and smaller-than-average object or vehicle.

It can be used to refer to handmade items or boats, typically ones that are smaller in size. For example, a small wooden boat made by hand is referred to as a "craft.".

Craft typically refers to smaller handmade objects, while ship typically refers to larger vessels used for transportation.

Galleon.wordDefinition:
A galleon is a specific type of ship that was prominent in the 16th to 18th centuries. It was characterized by its high forecastle and aftcastle, and a usually heavily armed.

A ship is a general term that encompasses all types of seafaring vessels, including but not limited to galleons.

A galleon is a specific type of ship, while ship is a more general term that refers to any seafaring vessel.

Liner.wordDefinition:
A liner refers to a type of ship that is used primarily for transporting passengers and cargo on a fixed route. These ships have a regular schedule for departures and arrivals, and the focus is on providing comfort and amenities for passengers during the journey.

Liners may have additional facilities like swimming pools, restaurants, and entertainment areas.

A liner is a specialized type of ship that focuses on passenger transport and providing amenities, while a ship is a more general term that refers to any vessel used for transport.

Schooner.wordDefinition:
A schooner is a type of sailboat that has two or more masts with the forward mast being shorter or equal in height to the rear mast.

Schooners are typically smaller and used for fishing or coastal trade.

A schooner is a smaller sailboat used for coastal activities while a ship is a larger vessel used for oceanic voyages and transportation of goods and people.

Vessel.wordDefinition:
Ship generally refers to a larger vessel that is designed for transportation of people or goods across bodies of water.

It is often used to describe cargo ships, naval vessels, or passenger ships.

Vessel is a broader term that can refer to any type of watercraft. This includes boats, yachts, ferries, and even fishing vessels.

A ship is typically a larger vessel that is designed for transportation over long distances, while a vessel can refer to any type of watercraft.

Yacht.wordDefinition:
A ship is a large vessel used for transportation of goods or people, while a yacht is a recreational vessel used for pleasure cruises or racing.

Ships are typically much larger than yachts and are used for commercial purposes such as cargo transport or military operations.

Yachts are smaller and usually owned by wealthy individuals for leisure activities such as sightseeing, fishing, or hosting parties.

Essentially, a ship is used for work and a yacht is used for play.

quotes.Text: I did get to hang out with my dad for a little while. I went with him to summer stock. I watched him be a real king of the world. He'd ship out as a star in summer stock. He sometimes directed the shows. I learned a lot from him - not just about acting, but about everything, how to handle a woman.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: David Carradine

quotes.Text: That's what so great about making movies. It's that you get to do stuff you never would be able to do in real life. You get to go to a recording studio, you get to go to Navy ships and fly all over the world for press. And it's just a great job.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: DJ Qualls

quotes.Text: I've always been fascinated by the Chinese. This goes a long way back to my childhood. The Chinese invented money, movable type, clocks, and built the largest ships in the history of the world.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Thomas Steinbeck

quotes.Text: Life is for living and there is only one way to go - unless you are prepared to sink and go down with the ship, which I don't choose to do.
quotes.Name: Kym Marsh

quotes.Text: All the artists out there, I ask you and beg you: Take over your ship. It's your career. It's your life.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Garth Brooks

quotes.Text: If I had my will I would live in a ship on the sea, and never come nearer to humanity than that!
quotes.Title: Italian Actress
quotes.Name: Eleonora Duse

quotes.Text: I spent more time on dark ships in danger zones than any other woman in the world.
quotes.Title: Australian Celebrity
quotes.Name: Elizabeth Kenny

quotes.Text: We may have all come on different ships, but we're in the same boat now.
quotes.Title: American Leader
quotes.Name: Martin Luther King, Jr.

quotes.Text: I am not afraid of storms for I am learning how to sail my ship.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.Text: If the ship is sinking, you need help getting off that ship.
quotes.Title: English Journalist
quotes.Name: Richard Quest
